docs.lead_paragraph: The most important words about the budget today were probably ones unsaid. President Clinton did not revive proposals like a sweeping health-care plan or a tax increase on the wealthy that Republicans would be bound to dismiss out of hand.

headline.main: Even With Agreement, A Goal Remains Elusive

docs.abstract: David E Rosenbaum analysis contends that Clinton Administration and Republican Congressional leaders are starting year with attitude that they can strike deal to bring Federal budget into balance by 2002; maintains that prevailing view in capital is that negotiations will succeed; says that does not mean budget will ever be balanced (M)
docs.snippet: The most important words about the budget today were probably ones unsaid.    President Clinton did not revive proposals like a sweeping health-care plan or a tax increase on the wealthy that Republicans would be bound to dismiss out of hand.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton moved today to provide health care coverage to half of the 10 million American children who have no health insurance, and proposed a new program to finance medical care for several million people between jobs. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said these initiatives would cost $2.8 billion next year and $18.4 billion over the five-year period from 1998 through 2002.

headline.main: President Moves to Protect Half of Uninsured Children

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton's budget would provide health care coverage to half of 10 million American children who have no health insurance; Administration has proposed new program to finance medical care for several million people between jobs; Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala says these initiatives would cost $2.8 billion next year and $18.4 billion over five-year period through 2002 (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton moved today to provide health care coverage to half of the 10 million American children who have no health insurance, and proposed a new program to finance medical care for several million people between jobs.    Donna E. Shalala,...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 North Korea to Take Taiwan's Nuclear Waste North Korea agreed to accept nuclear waste from Taiwan in exchange for much-needed hard currency. South Korea was outraged, because of the safety risks and because it wants to avoid inheriting liability for the waste in the event of North Korea's collapse. A1 Sotheby Executives Accused Sotheby's, the world's oldest and best known auction house, suspended several senior executives amid charges that they readily offered their services to smuggle a protected work of art out of Italy. Sotheby's denied that such abuses were systematic and said the journalism used in the investigation constituted entrapment. A9 Ecuador Chief Loses a Vote Ecuador's Congress voted to remove President Abdala Bucaram for ''mental incapacity.'' Lawmakers said they were exasperated by his six months in office, during which the President sang and pulled political stunts while Ecuador fell into economic crisis. Mr. Bucaram, a showman who cheerfully referred to himself as ''El Loco,'' called the vote a ''coup by Congress'' and said he would not recognize it. A5 Riots in South Africa Mixed-race South Africans, known as coloreds under apartheid laws, held a violent protest in Johannesburg. It erupted as part of a demonstration against local utility rates they said were higher than those in nearby black areas of Soweto. But it also reflected fears of many mixed-race people that they are being left out of the new South Africa. A15 Gore Meets Chernomyrdin Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin of Russia said that a summit meeting between Presidents Clinton and Boris Yeltsin would be held in late March, as scheduled. Mr. Chernomyrdin was in Washington for two days of talks with Vice President Al Gore. Progress on crucial matters between the two countries, like the question of NATO enlargement and other security issues, has been immobilized for the last six months by Mr. Yeltsin's illness. A19 No Progress in Peru Crisis Two hours of negotiations between leftist rebels in Peru and a commission chosen to represent the Government produced little if any progress towards the release of 72 hostages held inside the Japanese Ambassador's residence for more than seven weeks. The rebels denied that they were willing to discuss safe passage to a third country and sought to disparage a recent diplomatic tour by President Alberto Fujimori. A7 Opposition Struggles in Serbia Although President Slobodan Milosevic has recommended the restoration of opposition victories in 14 of Serbia's largest cities, the opposition may have a tough time governing: departing officials of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist party have left municipal coffers bare and are organizing resistance to the new administrations. A13 NATIONAL A20-27 Clinton Offers a Budget Intended to Reach Balance President Clinton introduced a $1.69 trillion spending plan for 1998 as a step to producing a balanced budget by 2002. He called it ''the best chance in a generation'' to balance the budget. A1 The Clinton budget has the glow of newness on it, but already the White House is working on elements of a compromise with Republicans, most likely including some sort of cut in the capital gains tax. A1 President Clinton asked Congress to provide health care for half of the 10 million children without health insurance. A25 The budget seeks $21 billion over five years to restore benefits to legal immigrants, reverse cuts in the food stamp program and create jobs for welfare recipients. A25 Simpson Suit Focuses on Money The families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman urged the jury weighing punitive damages against O. J. Simpson to make an example of him. Lawyers for Mr. Simpson said he was already $850,000 in debt and had no hidden assets to draw on. He has already been assessed $8.5 million in compensatory damages for Mr. Goldman's death. A20 Discard Cynicism, Clinton Says Telling the annual National Prayer Breakfast that politicians needed to rid themselves of ''this toxic atmosphere of cynicism,'' President Clinton invoked self-criticism and called for a moratorium on the politics of blame to concentrate more on working together. A26 Transportation Chief Confirmed The man who headed the Arkansas Highway Commission under Gov. Bill Clinton, Rodney Slater, was confirmed as Transportation Secretary under President Clinton. Mr. Slater is the fifth of Mr. Clinton's nominees to receive Senate confirmation. A22 Arrest in Clinic Attacks A 15-year-old in a Tulsa suburb was arrested by Federal agents on charges that he bombed and shot up an abortion clinic. A27 Youth Catches S.A.T. Error Colin Rizzio, a 17-year-old from Peterborough, N.H., encountered trouble on a question on the S.A.T. math test. The question had already been reviewed by a dozen people, and the College Board did not initially agree with his assertion that the officially approved answer was wrong. But after his E-mail inquiry and some review, the board is now sheepishly conceding that he was right -- and adding up to 30 points to the scores of some 45,000 of the students who took that test. A1 Dog May Get a Pardon Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and the state's Executive Council asked the town of Portsmouth to pardon a 3-year-old Labrador retriever, Prince, who faces execution for killing a rooster. A hearing is scheduled, and the City Attorney has said he wants to settle out of court. (Reuters) NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Passenger Jet Is Forced To Evade 2 Fighters A Boeing 727 passenger jet bound for Kennedy International Airport had to take sudden evasive actions after one or two F-16 fighter jets from the New Jersey Air National Guard repeatedly converged on it. Two flight attendants and a passenger were thrown to the 727's floor. A1 Police Union Investigated A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed 10 years of financial records from New York City's 29,000-member police union. The subpoena came two weeks after officials and lawyers of the smaller transit police union were indicted on racketeering charges. It is the first public indication that the investigation is now focusing on the politically potent Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. A1 More Environmental Spending The Pataki administration said it would speed up its plans to spend money from a bond act for environmental projects. In his budget last month, the Governor projected spending only about $500 million over five years from the bond act, far less than the $900 million he had suggested as he campaigned for it last fall. B1 No to Desegregation Plan The Whitman administration refused to order desegregation of a predominately black and Hispanic high school in Englewood, N.J. Officials said any plan to merge Englewood with the largely white school districts of surrounding Bergen County towns would increase the school's racial imbalance. B4 Airport Expansion Approved The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved spending $93 million to extend one of the runways at Newark International Airport. The project is expected to help curtail delays of up to 90 minutes at the airport, and will also allow Newark to accommodate larger, nonstop flights to the Far East and the farthest South American cities. B7 SPORTS B9-16 WEEKEND C1-33 BUSINESS DAY D1-17 America Online to Expand America Online Inc. said it would add 50,000 more modems to its on-line service by April, increasing its daily capacity by 60 percent, two months ahead of its previously announced timetable. D1 Business Digest D1 OBITUARIES D18 Milton Berger The Coney Island press agent who trumpeted the delights of Brooklyn's legendary amusement district so long and with such flamboyant verve that he became a local landmark was 81. D18 EDITORIAL A32-33 Editorials: Swiss bankers' gesture, making the budget bearable, New York City shortchanged, civility upbraided. Columns: A. M. Rosenthal, Bob Herbert, Anthony Lewis. Chronicle B8 Crossword C32 Weather B8

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal grand jury has subpoenaed 10 years of financial records from New York City's 29,000-member police union as part of a widening investigation into allegations of corruption. The subpoena, which comes two weeks after officials and lawyers of the smaller transit police union were indicted on racketeering charges, is the first public indication that the investigation is now focusing on the politically potent Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

headline.main: GRAND JURY SEEKS FINANCIAL RECORDS FROM POLICE UNION

docs.abstract: Federal grand jury subpoenas 10 years of financial records from New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association; subpoena, which comes two weeks after officials and lawyers of transit police union were indicted on racketeering charges, is first public indication that investigation is now focusing on PBA; Richard Hartman, James J Lysaght and Peter L Kramer, lawyers accused of paying kickbacks to officials of transit officer's union, have also worked for city PBA for over 15 years (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The basic outlines of President Clinton's budget for 1998 were largely set the moment he made election-year concessions to the Republicans to balance the budget by the year 2002, cut taxes and ax welfare spending. But now that he must live within these tight confines, Mr. Clinton has mostly made sound, compassionate decisions to mitigate the worst harshness. His budget plan would remove the cruelest parts of the welfare law by reinstating the right of childless adults to collect food stamps if they are unemployed and unable to find work. The plan would also allow legal immigrants who become disabled after they arrive in the United States to collect cash assistance and Medicaid coverage. It would provide health coverage for many uninsured children and extend health insurance for millions of workers between jobs.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that basic outlines of Pres Clinton's budget for 1998 were largely set moment he made election-year concessions to Republicans to balance budget by year 2002, cut taxes and ax welfare spending; maintains that now that he must live within these tight confines, Clinton has mostly made sound, compassionate decisions to mitigate worst harshness (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today proposed a $1.69 trillion budget for 1998 that he said would cut taxes on the middle class, increase spending on education and health care and lead to an end to deficits by 2002 -- and for almost 20 years after that. The Administration said it would achieve its deficit-reduction goals over the next five years with a $350 billion bundle of program cuts and tax increases, including slowing the growth of Medicare and extending some taxes, like those on airline tickets, that are set to expire.

headline.main: Clinton Presents '98 Budget, and a Goal

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton plans to lower Government spending over the next five years by $252 billion, even as he increases spending -- sometimes dramatically -- on some of Government's most popular programs, from welfare to education to the environment to tax relief. So how does he do that?

headline.main: Clinton's Budget Holds Few Clues on Exactly How to Lower Spending

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton plans to lower Government spending over next five years by $252 billion, even as he increases spending on some of Government's most popular programs; Clinton's budget offers some answers on how he intends to do it, but not with great clarity (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Joseph L. Bruno, the New York Senate majority leader, says women in New York ''enjoy a measure of security'' thanks to our mandate for health insurance coverage of mammograms (letter, Feb. 4). Yet for two years he has blocked a bill supported by most of the Senate requiring insurers to cover scientifically sound treatments that take place in clinical trials. Mr. Bruno should allow the Senate to enact the law that would give cancer patients and others real peace of mind. MARK SCHERZER Legislative Counsel, New Yorkers for Accessible Health Coverage New York, Feb. 4, 1997
docs.abstract: Mark Scherzer letter contends that New York State Senate Majority Leader Joseph L Bruno has blocked bill that would require health insurers to cover scientifically sound treatments for breast cancer that take place in clinical trials

docs.lead_paragraph: When city officials here gave unanimous approval last year to an ordinance requiring companies that work with the municipal government to offer health and other benefits to the unmarried partners of their employees, it seemed an easy civil rights victory for San Francisco's influential gay and lesbian constituency. But with nearly four months to go before the ordinance is to take effect, the measure is having to fight its way through a gantlet of criticism from small businesses, big corporations and the Roman Catholic Church.

headline.main: Opposition in San Francisco to Unmarried-Partners Policy

docs.abstract: Small businesses, big corporations and Roman Catholic Church oppose San Francisco ordinance requiring companies that work with municipal government to offer health and other benefits to unmarried partners of their employees; ordinance will take effect on June 1 (M)
